thread.title: See Faith's Josh Donaldson homer off Wallace State's Derek Holland in the MLB playoffs
thread.title_full: See Faith's Josh Donaldson homer off Wallace State's Derek Holland in the MLB playoffs | AL.com

author: Mark Inabinett | minabinett@al.com
title: See Faith's Josh Donaldson homer off Wallace State's Derek Holland in the MLB playoffs
text:
Two players with Alabama baseball roots squared off in Game 4 of the American League Division Series between the Texas Rangers and the Toronto Blue Jays on Monday.
Toronto third baseman Josh Donaldson , a baseball and football star at Faith Academy in Mobile before playing baseball at Auburn , came to the plate in the top of the first inning against Texas pitcher Derek Holland , who was a standout at Wallace State in Hanceville.
Toronto leadoff batter Ben Revere had bunted his way on base to open the game. Donaldson followed by hammering a 1-0 pitch for an opposite-field home run off the left-hander.
Your browser does not support iframes. The Blue Jays must win on Monday to force a deciding game in the best-of-five series on Wednesday.
Donaldson homered in the second game of the series on Friday, too, after leaving the opener on Thursday as a precaution feeling light-headed following a collision at second base.
RELATED: JOSH DONALDSON LEAVES AL PLAYOFF GAME AFTER COLLISON AT SECOND BASE
Donaldson hit a career-high 41 home runs during the regular season, when he led the American League in runs and RBIs.
RELATED: JOSH DONALDSON MATCHES HANK AARON FEAT
Holland was on the Wallace State team that went to the NJCAA World Series in 2006.
Holland won 38 games for the Texas Rangers from 2011 through 2013, but knee surgery limited him to six games in 2014. He took the mound on April 10 to start the 2015 season, but that outing lasted just one inning. A strained shoulder kept Holland out of action until Aug. 19. He made nine starts down the stretch for the Rangers, including a shutout of the Baltimore Orioles on Aug. 30. Holland went 4-3 with a 4.91 ERA. In 58.2 innings, he struck out 41 and walked 17.
Holland had a 3-0 postseason record entering Monday's game, with his most recent victory coming in the 2011 World Series.
